title: Which is better and why: Udemy or Coursera? - Quora

response.answer_text: That depends on what you’re looking forward to. When it comes to price, now that Coursera has a fixed monthly payment option (you pay US$50 to make as many courses as you’d like to), I think it’s all a matter of deciding how much time you’re willing to spend on online courses every month to see which of these will end up being cheaper to you. Udemy may be cheaper if you take courses at a slower rates or in smaller quantities, but not so if you have lots of spare time to invest in lots of courses. However, the differences aren’t only in price and payment methods. For example, whereas Udemy has courses developed by individuals, Coursera has mainly academic courses from top-notch universities. This may seem like a huge advantage for Coursera, as you know, *CERTIFICATES*, but it comes with a few problems. For instance, you will never see an university offering a “Microsoft Office Course” nor anything like that. Of course, universities teach their alumni to use this sort of software, but always as part of some bigger subject. So, if you’re looking forward to understand a software that may be useful to your career, be it Excel, Autocad or Photoshop, it may prove hard to find the right course for you in Coursera. Even though I’ve learnt many functionalities of Excel by doing courses related to developing models to simulate business scenarios in Coursera, this is different from being taught how to use the software per se. There are many “advanced” and/ or even “intermediate” things on Excel that I may not be able to use, even if some tools that I’ve been dealing with are considered advanced. And anyone who tries to use Coursera to learn how to use a given software is going to experience these problems. Of course, this more “focused” way to learn software has its bright side too. If you know exactly what you’re going to do with Excel in real life, you’re only saving time by skipping everything that isn’t useful for your specific case. But Udemy proofs to be a better contender if you want to learn how to use a given software in a more complete fashion. And this is only an example of how these platforms are different from each other and of how both of them can be the best for you in different situations.

With more than 80,000 courses most topics are covered and taught by experts. The courses are available on demand so that the learning is possible anywhere at any time, on the own pace. Udemy courses are available in 80 languages. Offering more than 80,000 online courses with many available free of charge, there is definitely something for everyone from business to personal interests. It focuses on helping professionals long out of the university system to keep up with ever-changing workplaces. About 30%, meanwhile, are taking “personal development” courses with subject matter ranging from music to fitness. To Udemy CEO D. Yang, that split is a sign that people increasingly view education as an investment upon which they expect a quantifiable return.
